text:
Coding tools treat code as static structured text.

UX design tools treat design as static vector-graphics with "noodles for swapping a 1000 static states" on top.

Code is data that needs direct manipulation with instant feedback. That's what creative tools need to achieve.

elements.text:
Coding tools treat code as static structured text.

UX design tools treat design as static vector-graphics with "noodles for swapping a 1000 static states" on top.

Code is data that needs direct manipulation with instant feedback. That's what creative tools need to achieve.

text: To clarify, the "direct manipulation of code" needs to be supported as a visual canvas that shows the running product you're working on. The design tool needs to work back from there to materialize any direct manipulations you've made as corresponding code changes in real time.

elements.text: To clarify, the "direct manipulation of code" needs to be supported as a visual canvas that shows the running product you're working on. The design tool needs to work back from there to materialize any direct manipulations you've made as corresponding code changes in real time.

text:
Been on a Vagus nerve binge and someone recommended this great TED talk <https://www.ted.com/talks/heribert_watzke_the_brain_in_your_gut>

If the CNS is a collection of agents, might there be some 10x-100x-Nx agents, and would the "gut" be one?

attachments.fallback: TED Video: Heribert Watzke: The brain in your gut
attachments.text: Did you know you have functioning neurons in your intestines -- about a hundred million of them? Food scientist Heribert Watzke tells us about the "hidden brain" in our gut and the surprising things it makes us feel.
attachments.title: Heribert Watzke: The brain in your gut

elements.text: Been on a Vagus nerve binge and someone recommended this great TED talk
If the CNS is a collection of agents, might there be some 10x-100x-Nx agents, and would the "gut" be one?
